name: MY CRIMSON, NOT YOURS.
description: Is there a way to make a color pun and somehow mix it with a serious narrative with generational trauma? Yes! Of course there is. Not all puns are supposed to be funny; an irony of humor I suppose. In, "MY CRIMSON, NOT YOURS.", we start off with a ridiculous and declarative statement of someone claiming ownership over a color; crimson. By stating the words this way, we've created a hierarchy of a have/have not scenario or possibly a dispute between parties. We then add the letter "E" to CRIMSON to make two words: CRIME and SON. Each successive line below the previous moves MY CRIME and SON further and further apart from each other, intimating that something wrong has happened and that the parent and son aren't communicating or having a breakdown in their relationship. What was the crime? Was the crime that the person stole or claimed ownership of crimson? Was this crime so bad that the son has separated from their parent? We're left wondering as if we just witnessed a slice of life in another family's social dynamic and saw the sad reality that so many families quietly face, disconnection.
